abstracts.cdata!:
The Forestry Project for Burkina Faso
            achieved mixed results. The project is a semi-success in
            terms of its forestry sector approach and in view of the
            objectives assigned to it during appraisal. However,
            experience acquired by the Bank over the 1980s has shown
            that only a multisectoral and participatory approach can
            generate solutions to the problem of natural resource
            degradation in West Africa. From this perspective, the
            project's conception was limited and its impact has
            been slight. The project's implementation was hampered
            by the reorganization and constant staff changes in the
            Ministry of Environment, and most importantly by the
            Government's delay in providing counterpart funds. Even
            after the project was revised to reduce the
            Government's share of operating expenses, ultimately a
            significant portion of the IDA credit was undisbursed and
            cancelled. The project did achieve a number of physical
            accomplishments, including: (i) construction of offices;
            (ii) maintenance and exploitation of existing plantations;
            (iii) planting and maintenance of new plantations; (iv)
            management of natural forests; and (v) production and
            distribution of seedlings. While the project did succeed in
            strengthening the Forestry Administration, the
            sustainability of these results is questionable. Many of the
            results were difficult to monitor and quantify. Still, the
            project provided a building block for the definition of the
            more comprehensive approach which, as of 1990, is being
            developed in Burkina Faso.

docna.cdata!:
Upper Volta - Forestry Project : Credit 0982
            - Development Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Upper Volta - Forestry Project :
            Credit 0982 - Development Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed project provides a
            comprehensive program to strengthen the operational capacity
            of the Forestry Administration with staff and equipment to
            carry out its assigned functions of protecting, developing
            and, exploiting the country's forest resources, within
            the framework of the national forestry plan. The project
            would also establish 1,600 ha of rainfed tree plantations
            and 325 ha of rural woodlots in the Bobo-Dioulasso area,
            manage on a pilot basis 1000 ha of natural forest in the
            Maro reserve and maintain previously established rainfed
            tree plantations. The project would finance (a) civil works
            for the Forestry Administration and Maro reserve; (b)
            vehicles and equipment; (c) personnel, office, vehicle and
            equipment operating costs; (d) expert services to advise the
            Forestry Administration, to implement and monitor the
            forestry operations under the project and to carry out
            studies; and (e) field training and fellowships.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Forestry Project for Upper Volta
            provides a comprehensive program to strengthen the
            operational capacity of the forestry administration with
            staff and equipment to carry out its assigned functions of
            protecting, developing and exploiting the country's
            forest resources, within the framework of the national
            forestry plan. The project will also establish 1,600 ha of
            rainfed tree plantations and 325 ha of rural woodlots in the
            Bobo-Dioulasso area, manage on a pilot basis 1000 ha of
            natural forest in the Maro reserve and maintain previously
            established rainfed tree plantations. The project will
            finance: (a) civil works for the Forestry Administration and
            Maro reserve; (b) vehicles and equipment; (c) personnel,
            office, vehicle and equipment operating costs; (d) expert
            services to advise the forestry administration, to implement
            and monitor the forestry operations under the project and to
            carry out studies; and (e) field training and fellowships.
